details.purpose: Za zapisovanje različnih statusov, ki se ponavadi uporablja za aplikacijskimi in kliničnimi sporočili, ki so odvisna od definirane vsebine
details.use: Za dodeljevanje pravic EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.v1 archetype, dodaja informacije za povezovanje.
details.misuse: It should not be assumed that these qualifiers are safely interoperable unless further definition and alignment is agreed between all sharing parties. A problem which has been defined as 'Inactive' during a hospital admission cannot be assumed to be regarded as 'Inactive' in a primary care setting , where a much longer term perspective is being taken. Similarly terms such as Initial, Interim and Final, whilst helpful to the human observer are unlikely to be precisely enough defined to be safely computable e.g. for decision support.

details.purpose: To record various status and context qualifiers which though commonly used within applications and in clinical messages but which are highly contextually dependent or variably defined and used in practice.
details.use: Use to qualify an EVALUATION.problem_diagnosis.v1 archetype, adding context and state specific information. These qualifiers should be used with care as they are variably used in practice and interopaerablility cannot be assured unless usage is clearly defined within the community of sharing.
details.misuse: It should not be assumed that these qualifiers are safely interoperable unless further definition and alignment is agreed between all sharing parties. A problem which has been defined as 'Inactive' during a hospital admission cannot be assumed to be regarded as 'Inactive' in a primary care setting , where a much longer term perspective is being taken. Similarly terms such as Initial, Interim and Final, whilst helpful to the human observer are unlikely to be precisely enough defined to be safely computable e.g. for decision support.

items.description: Additional status and contextual qualifiers factors related to a problem/diagnosis.
Episodicity is used within a primary care context to distinguish between ongoing and new episodes of a problem or diagnosis, primarily for public health or quality assessment purposes.
The degree to which the problem is active and relevant within the current clinical context.

Records temporal/evidential progress towards identification of the problem or diagnosis, recognising that precise identification may take time to evolve as increasing amounts of evidence become available.

A numeric or textual representation of the priority assigned to the problem, relative to other problems in a list. This may be used to sort items according to perceived clinical priority or to filter problems felt to be of greater /lesser significance.
A flag or text/ coded item recording whether this problem/diagnosis should be presented in a patient summary. Applications may implement this in a variety of ways.
The diagnosis has been made at the outset of the diagnostic process with limited evidence available.
The problem or diagnosis has been identified with some confidence but further evidence has yet to be considered.
The problem or diagnosis is made at the end of the diagnostic process taking into account all available significant evidence. It is not expected to change.
Description of the impact of the problem or diagnosis on the patient as a whole. Unlike 'severity' this can be used to compare the clinical impact of different problems.
The problem or diagnosis is currently active and clinically relevant.
The problem or diagnosis is not completely resolved but is inactive or felt less relevant to the current clinical context.
The problem or diagnosis is completely resolved and therefore not relevant to the current clinical context.
The level of confidence in the identification of the problem or diagnosis.
The first ever occurence of this problem or diagnosis.
A new occurence of an existing problem or diagnosis.
Part of an ongoing occurence of an existing problem or diagnosis.
The problem has had no impact on the subject.
The problem has had very little overall impact on the subject's life or health.
The problem has had considerable overall impact on the subject's life or health.
The problem has threatened the subject's life.
A text comment on the active status e.g describing the circumstances or evidence for resolution of a problem.
The problem was fatal to the subject.
The probem has been identified with a low level of certainty.
The probem has been identified with only a moderate level of certainty.
The probem has been identified with a high level of certainty.
The probem has been identified with a very-high level of certainty.
The probem has been identified and confirmed against recognised criteria.
Cateories of problem/ diagnosis/issue.
The issue is a condition.
The issue is a symptom.
The issue is a clinical finding.
The issue is a patient complaint.
The issue is a functional limitation.
The issue is recognised to be causing a problem.
The issue is regarded as a biomedical diagnosis.
The problem or issue is of a recurring nature but is currently quiescent.
Temporal context indicator aligned with SNOMEDCT.
An issue occuring in the past.
An issue which ocurred at present.

In episodic care contexts (commonly secondary care) it is common to categorise/ organise problems according to their relationship to the principal problem or diagnosis being addressed during that episode of care. These categories may also be used for clinical coding, reporting and billing purposes.
The main condition treated or investigated during the relevant episode of care.
A co-morbidity is a condition that exists at the start of the episode of care, which requires treatment, diagnostic procedures or increased clinical care/monitoring.
A complication is a condition not present at the start of the episode of care which arises during the episode of care, or is a result of a procedure or treatment during that episode.
Any other problem or issue deemed significant to the patient's care which does not fall into the one of other categories.
The main procedure performed during the relevant episode of care.
The level of confidence in the identification of the problem or diagnosis. (synthesised)
Description of the impact of the problem or diagnosis on the patient as a whole. Unlike 'severity' this can be used to compare the clinical impact of different problems. (synthesised)
Cateories of problem/ diagnosis/issue. (synthesised)
The degree to which the problem is active and relevant within the current clinical context. (synthesised)

Records temporal/evidential progress towards identification of the problem or diagnosis, recognising that precise identification may take time to evolve as increasing amounts of evidence become available. (synthesised)
Temporal context indicator aligned with SNOMEDCT. (synthesised)
Episodicity is used within a primary care context to distinguish between ongoing and new episodes of a problem or diagnosis, primarily for public health or quality assessment purposes. (synthesised)

In episodic care contexts (commonly secondary care) it is common to categorise/ organise problems according to their relationship to the principal problem or diagnosis being addressed during that episode of care. These categories may also be used for clinical coding, reporting and billing purposes. (synthesised)
